questions.text: A 40-year-old obese woman with hypertriglyceridemia presents with gradually progressive darkening and thickening of the skin over the neck and axillae. On examination, the skin appears velvety. She has recently started on a lipid-lowering agent. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this dermatosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nicotinic acid is a well-recognised cause of drug-induced acanthosis nigricans (AN), especially when used in high doses to treat hyperlipidemia. The condition is characterised by velvety, hyperpigmented plaques typically involving the neck, axillae, and groin, often accompanied by skin tags.

Acanthosis Nigricans (AN):

  • Definition: Symmetrical, velvety hyperpigmentation and thickening of the skin, typically in intertriginous areas.
  • Associated with:
    • Obesity
    • Type 2 diabetes
    • Endocrinopathies (Cushing syndrome, acromegaly)
    • Genetic syndromes
    • Malignancies (e.g., gastric carcinoma – more extensive involvement)
    • Medications (drug-induced AN)

Explanation of Other Options:

Hydrochlorothiazide (Option A): Not associated with acanthosis nigricans. It can cause photosensitive lichenoid eruptions, especially on sun-exposed areas, and may also lead to hyperpigmentation via melanocyte stimulation.

Amiodarone (Option B): Does not cause acanthosis nigricans. Causes a characteristic blue-grey pigmentation over sun-exposed skin due to dermal deposition of lipophilic drug complexes with melanin.

Phenytoin (Option D): Not linked to AN development. Known for gingival hyperplasia, acneiform eruptions, and coarsening of facial features with long-term use. It can also cause follicular hyperkeratosis and drug-induced lupus.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/ are associated with Acanthosis nigricans?
1. Carcinoma stomach
2. Obesity
3. Insulin resistance
4. Hemochromatosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Carcinoma stomach, obesity, and insulin resistance are all well-established associations with Acanthosis nigricans (AN). Hemochromatosis is not associated.

  • AN has two major forms: benign (common) and malignant (rare).
  • Benign AN is strongly associated with insulin resistance and obesity, particularly in individuals with metabolic syndrome or PCOS.
  • Gastric adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy linked with malignant AN.

Acanthosis Nigricans (AN) is a disorder of keratinisation that presents with hyperpigmented, thickened, and velvety plaques commonly over the neck, axillae, and groin.

Benign AN is associated with:

  • Obesity
  • Insulin resistance (Type 2 diabetes, PCOS, HAIR-AN syndrome)
  • Endocrinopathies (acromegaly, hypothyroidism)
  • Drugs (nicotinic acid, corticosteroids, insulin)

Malignant AN is a paraneoplastic syndrome most commonly associated with:

  • Gastric adenocarcinoma (>60%)
  • Other gastrointestinal, genitourinary, and lung cancers

Pathophysiology:

  • Involves IGF-1, TGF-α, and FGFR mutations leading to keratinocyte and fibroblast proliferation

Histopathology:

  • Hyperkeratosis, papillomatosis, and no significant melanocytic proliferation

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • HAIR-AN Syndrome: HyperAndrogenism + Insulin Resistance + Acanthosis Nigricans
  • Syndromic associations: PCOS, Cushing’s, hypothyroidism, genetic syndromes (e.g., Beare–Stevens, SADDAN)
  • Malignancy workup is essential in sudden-onset or extensive AN in older adults
  • Treatment: Addressing the underlying cause (e.g., weight loss, managing insulin resistance, discontinuing causative drugs)

Key Takeaways:

  • Acanthosis nigricans is most commonly associated with insulin resistance and obesity.
  • Gastric adenocarcinoma is the malignancy most frequently associated with malignant AN.
  • Hemochromatosis is not an associated condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old malnourished man presents with complaints of persistent diarrhoea and cognitive disturbances. On examination, he has well-demarcated, symmetric, hyperpigmented, scaly, and erythematous plaques on sun-exposed areas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pellagra, caused by niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency, classically presents with the triad of dermatitis, diarrhoea, and dementia, eventually leading to death if untreated.

  • Niacin (Vitamin B3) is essential for forming NAD and NADP, which are crucial for redox reactions.
  • Pellagra manifests with:
    • Dermatitis: Painful/pruritic redness and oedema in photodistributed areas → evolves into sharply marginated, hyperpigmented and keratotic plaques.
      • Common sites: Dorsal hands, face in butterfly distribution, neck and upper chest (Casal’s necklace).
      • Severe cases: Vesicles and bullae.
    • Gastrointestinal symptoms: Early presentation includes anorexia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea.
    • Neuropsychiatric symptoms: Apathy, irritability, insomnia, memory impairment → can progress to dementia and psychosis.
    • Mucosal signs: Angular stomatitis, glossitis, cheilitis, oral/perirectal ulcers.
    • Half-and-half nails may be seen.
  • Pellagra is mainly diagnosed clinically, but can be supported by reduced urinary niacin metabolites and serum levels.
  • Treatment: Oral nicotinamide (500 mg/day); neuropsychiatric symptoms improve in 24–48 hrs, but skin symptoms may take weeks.
  • At-risk groups: Malnutrition, maize-based diets, chronic alcoholism, malabsorption, dialysis patients, certain drugs (e.g. isoniazid, estrogens), carcinoid syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

Lichen planus (Option A): Violaceous, flat-topped papules with Wickham’s striae; not photodistributed or associated with systemic signs like diarrhoea or dementia.

Acrodermatitis Enteropathica (Option C): A genetic disorder of zinc absorption, classically presenting with a triad of dermatitis, alopecia, and diarrhoea.

SLE (Option D) – Malar rash may mimic the butterfly rash, but lacks the hyperkeratotic, Casal necklace distribution and systemic triad of pellagra.

Key Takeaways:

  • Think pellagra in a patient with photodistributed rash, diarrhoea, and neurocognitive symptoms.
  • Casal’s necklace and butterfly rash in pellagra have well-defined hyperpigmented and keratotic features.
  • Treat with nicotinamide, not nicotinic acid, to avoid flushing/headache.

questions.text: A child presents with lesions as shown below. This is a manifestation of deficiency of vitamin:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child exhibits phrynoderma, a characteristic cutaneous manifestation of vitamin A deficiency, presenting as keratotic follicular papules with generalised xerosis, most commonly on the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms.

  • Vitamin A deficiency affects ocular, mucosal, and cutaneous tissues.
  • Early signs:
    • Nyctalopia (night blindness) due to defective dark adaptation.
    • Xerophthalmia, Bitot’s spots, and later complications like keratomalacia, iris prolapse, and blindness.
  • Cutaneous features:
    • Xerosis (dry skin), dermomalacia (deep fissuring).
    • Phrynoderma (“toad skin”):
      • Keratotic follicular papules on anterolateral thighs, posterolateral upper arms, extensor extremities, shoulders, posterior neck, back, buttocks, and abdomen.
  • Other symptoms:
    • Hyposmia and hypogeusia due to aberrant mucosal keratinisation.
  • Phrynoderma is not specific to vitamin A deficiency and may also be seen with:
    • Vitamin B-complex, C, and E deficiencies
    • Zinc and essential fatty acid deficiency
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serum retinol level (<20 μg/dL is low)
  • Treatment:
    • Vitamin A 50,000–200,000 IU/day, depending on age and severity, until resolution.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Vitamin B deficiency (Option B): May cause phrynoderma, but not as strongly or characteristically as vitamin A. Other signs (cheilitis, glossitis, neuropathy) are typically present.
  • Vitamin C deficiency (Option C): Leads to scurvy, characterised by bleeding gums, perifollicular haemorrhages, and poor wound healing, not phrynoderma.
  • Vitamin D deficiency (option D): Causes rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults; no follicular keratosis or xerosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Phrynoderma = “toad skin” due to follicular hyperkeratosis + xerosis.
  • Most characteristically caused by vitamin A deficiency, though multifactorial.
  • Always consider night blindness and xerophthalmia as associated clues.
  • Treat with high-dose vitamin A and address underlying nutritional deficits.

questions.text: A malnourished child presents with peripheral oedema and characteristic skin findings described as 'cracked skin' with irregular fissuring and desquamation in areas of friction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The"flaky paint" or "crazy paving" dermatosis described with scale, fissuring, and plaques over friction-prone areas is characteristic of Kwashiorkor, a form of protein-energy malnutrition associated with hypoproteinaemia and oedema.

Protein-Energy Malnutrition:

  • Kwashiorkor results from protein deficiency despite adequate caloric intake, especially carbohydrates.
  • Cutaneous findings in Kwashiorkor:
    • Peripheral oedema due to hypoproteinaemia.
    • Skin lesions resembling "cracked enamel" or "flaky paint", with irregular desquamation and fissuring.
    • Lesions predominate in intertriginous/frictional areas.
    • Hair becomes brittle, shows a red-brown discolouration, and the flag sign (alternating bands of pigmentation) may be seen.
  • Other associated findings:
    • Hepatomegaly from fatty infiltration due to apolipoprotein deficiency.
    • Co-morbid vitamin and mineral deficiencies.
  • In contrast, Marasmus is characterised by caloric deficiency and shows severe wasting without oedema.

Explanation of other options:

Dermatitis (Option A): Non-specific term; many inflammatory conditions show skin changes, but flaky paint appearance with oedema is specific for Kwashiorkor. Dermatitis typically lacks systemic malnutrition signs.

Pellagra (Option B): Due to niacin deficiency. Presents with the classic triad of dermatitis, diarrhoea, and dementia. The dermatitis is classically photosensitive, affecting sun-exposed areas, not oedematous or flaky, paint-like.

Marasmus (Option C): Due to a global calorie deficiency. Characterised by wasting, loss of subcutaneous fat, loose wrinkled skin, but no oedema or flaky paint skin. Skin is thin, dry, and wrinkled - not desquamative or fissured.

Key Takeaways:

  • Kwashiorkor presents with:
    • Oedema, hepatomegaly, brittle red-brown hair
    • "Flaky paint" dermatitis: irregular, fissured desquamation
  • Marasmus: severe wasting without oedema or flaky paint skin.
  • Skin features are key for dermatologic diagnosis of malnutrition.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant, recently weaned from breastfeeding, presents with persistent diarrhoea, irritability, alopecia, and erythematous, crusted plaques involving the perioral, perianal, and acral areas. The lesions are sharply demarcated and show signs of secondary bacterial infection. What is the most likely underlying nutritional deficiency?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This presentation is classic for acrodermatitis enteropathica, a rare inherited or acquired disorder due to zinc deficiency.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the SLC39A4 gene, which encodes ZIP4, the main intestinal transporter of zinc, resulting in impaired zinc absorption and systemic zinc deficiency.

  • Zinc is a vital cofactor for numerous enzymes, and its deficiency affects organs with high cell turnover: skin, intestine, and the immune system.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Dermatitis around the mouth, anus, hands, and feet, starting soon after weaning
    • Skin lesions: erythema, vesicles, bullae, pustules, desquamation, crusting
    • Alopecia, blepharitis, conjunctivitis, photophobia
    • Diarrhoea, growth faltering, and recurrent infections
  • Diagnosis: Based on clinical features, low serum zinc (though it may be normal), and rapid response to zinc supplementation.
  • Treatment: Oral zinc sulphate 150–400 mg/day in children; requires lifelong supplementation.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • AE symptoms often begin at 4–10 weeks in formula-fed infants.
  • The disease can be fatal if untreated.
  • Monitoring for copper deficiency is necessary during treatment.

Explanation of Other Options:

Molybdenum (Option A):
Not implicated in acrodermatitis enteropathica. It’s a trace element essential for enzyme function but not related to ZIP4 or skin disease.

Copper (Option B):
Copper deficiency can lead to haematological and neurological issues, but not the classical triad seen in AE (dermatitis, alopecia, diarrhoea).

Calcium (Option D):
Involved in bone and neuromuscular health; deficiency does not cause AE.

Key Takeaways:

  • AE is a genetic zinc absorption disorder caused by SLC39A4 mutations.
  • Presents with periorificial/acral dermatitis, alopecia, and diarrhoea in infants.
  • Treatment is lifelong zinc supplementation, starting from infancy.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiencies is least likely to be associated with the development of phrynoderma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Phrynoderma is a form of follicular hyperkeratosis associated with nutritional deficiencies, most notably vitamin A deficiency, though it may also be linked to deficiencies of vitamin C, B complex vitamins, vitamin E, and essential fatty acids (EFAs). There is no evidence to support a causal role for vitamin D deficiency in the development of phrynoderma.

Phrynoderma:

  • Phrynoderma literally means toad skin and is one of the cutaneous manifestations of nutritional deficiency, most commonly vitamin A deficiency.
  • It presents as follicular hyperkeratotic papules with a central keratotic plug, often non-pruritic, and bilaterally distributed.
  • Most commonly involves elbows, knees, buttocks, and extensor surfaces of limbs.
  • Generalised disease may involve the trunk and face.
  • Often associated with ocular signs, including night blindness and conjunctival xerosis.
  • Nutritional deficiencies implicated include:
    • Vitamin A (Option B ruled out)
    • Vitamin C (Option C ruled out)
    • Vitamin E
    • Riboflavin and other B complex vitamins
    • Essential fatty acids (EFAs) (Option A ruled out)
  • Treatment includes oral multivitamin therapy, especially with vitamin A supplementation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Phrynoderma = nutritional follicular hyperkeratosis, primarily due to vitamin A deficiency.
  • Also associated with deficiencies of EFA, vitamin C, E, and B complex.
  • Vitamin D deficiency is NOT a cause.
  • Responds well to vitamin A supplementation and dietary correction.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child from a low-income rural area presents with generalised weakness, irritability, and failure to gain weight. On examination, the child has bilateral pedal oedema, hepatomegaly, and a distinctive dermatosis over intertriginous areas resembling flaky paint. Hair examination shows brittle strands with alternating light and dark bands of pigmentation.
Which of the following is the most likely underlying nutritional deficiency?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child presents with classical clinical features of kwashiorkor, a form of protein–energy malnutrition (PEM). The flag sign — alternating bands of light and dark pigmentation in the hair — is a hallmark of PEM due to cycles of malnutrition and relative refeeding.

PEM includes marasmus, kwashiorkor, and marasmic kwashiorkor, all of which affect the skin, hair, nails, and mucosa.

Flag Sign – Key Points:

  • Seen in kwashiorkor and marasmic kwashiorkor
  • Reflects nutritional cycling — i.e., alternating malnutrition and nutritional repletion
  • Often accompanied by:
    • Peripheral oedema
    • Flaky paint dermatosis
    • Hair changes: red–brown discolouration, brittle texture

Explanation of Other Options:

Zinc deficiency (Option A): Zinc deficiency causes acrodermatitis enteropathica, which manifests with periorificial and acral dermatitis, alopecia, and diarrhoea, with no flag sign.

Vitamin C deficiency (Option B): Causes scurvy, characterised by perifollicular haemorrhages, corkscrew hairs, and gum disease, but not a flag sign.

Marasmus (Option C): Does not produce a flag sign. Involves severe caloric deficiency with prominent muscle wasting, loss of subcutaneous fat, but no oedema or flaky dermatosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Flag sign = alternating bands of hair pigmentation due to PEM, especially kwashiorkor.
  • Accompanied by flaky paint skin, oedema, hepatomegaly, and mucosal changes.
  • Helps differentiate kwashiorkor from other nutritional disorders.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy from a low-income rural area is brought to the clinic by his parents with complaints of persistent lethargy, irritability, joint pain, and refusal to walk for the past 3 weeks. On examination, he has swollen, bleeding gums and perifollicular purpura with corkscrew hairs over his lower limbs. The parents report a diet poor in fruits and vegetables. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture of bleeding gums, perifollicular hemorrhages, corkscrew hairs, and arthralgia/pseudoparalysis is characteristic of vitamin C deficiency.Scurvy results from a deficiency of vitamin C, which is essential for collagen biosynthesis and maintaining vascular integrity.

Vitamin C Deficiency - Scurvy

  • Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is a water-soluble antioxidant required for:
    • Collagen synthesis
    • Carnitine and catecholamine metabolism
    • Enhancing non-heme iron absorption
  • Clinical onset of scurvy occurs 1–3 months after a vitamin C-deficient diet.
  • Cutaneous features:
    • Phrynoderma: Hyperkeratotic follicular papules, initially on the arms
    • Corkscrew hairs: Coiled/fractured hair due to faulty keratin cross-linking
    • Perifollicular haemorrhages and purpura, especially on the lower limbs
    • Splinter hemorrhages
  • Oral findings: Haemorrhagic gingivitis (red, shiny → necrotic, bleeding gums)
  • Diagnosis is clinical, supported by low leukocyte ascorbic acid levels
  • Treated with ascorbic acid 100–300 mg/day → rapid symptom resolution
  • Scurvy may mimic vasculitis, but the absence of systemic features and improvement with supplementation helps differentiate

Explanation of Other Options:

Vitamin A (Option A): Deficiency presents with xerosis, Bitot spots, and night blindness. No bleeding gums or corkscrew hairs. Involved in epithelial differentiation and vision.

Vitamin D (Option C): Deficiency leads to rickets (in children) or osteomalacia (in adults). Presents with bone deformities, not perifollicular purpura or gingival bleeding.

Vitamin K (Option D): Deficiency causes coagulopathy, leading to easy bruising and mucosal bleeding. But no corkscrew hairs or perifollicular haemorrhages; also, vitamin K is essential for clotting factor activation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Scurvy should be suspected in children with poor diets presenting with bleeding gums, joint pain, and characteristic skin findings.
  • Corkscrew hairs and perifollicular haemorrhages are pathognomonic.
  • Rapid response to ascorbic acid confirms the diagnosis.
  • Misdiagnosis as vasculitis is common—an important differential in purpuric skin lesions in children.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a 15-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with asymptomatic, well-demarcated, yellow-brown plaques with an atrophic center and a violaceous rim on the anterior aspect of both legs. She denies trauma or insect bites. The lesions have been slowly enlarging over several months. Laboratory investigations reveal adequate glycemic control. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Necrobiosis lipoidica is a granulomatous skin condition strongly associated with type 1 diabetes and typically presents on the pretibial area as yellow-brown atrophic plaques with a violaceous border.

  • Necrobiosis lipoidica (NLD):
    • A chronic granulomatous disorder affecting collagen.
    • It most often presents in middle-aged women with long-standing type 1 diabetes.
    • Lesions are well-circumscribed, atrophic, telangiectatic plaques with a yellow-brown centre and violaceous elevated border, usually on the pretibial surface.
    • Granulomatous inflammation with palisaded and interstitial histopathology is typical.
    • Ulceration can occur in longstanding lesions.
    • Only 22% of patients with NLD develop diabetes over time, though its association with type 1 DM is notable (seen in 2–3% of type 1 diabetics).
    • Glycemic control does not reliably alter disease course.
    • Treatment is unsatisfactory – topical or intralesional corticosteroids may help early/active lesions.

Explanation of other options:

Diabetic dermopathy (Option A):

Presents as small, round, brown, atrophic macules on shins; lacks the telangiectatic border and ulceration seen in NLD. The most common cutaneous manifestation of diabetes.

Pretibial myxedema (Option C):

Typically occurs in Graves’ disease; presents as firm, waxy, non-pitting plaques with a “peau d’orange” texture.

Related to mucin deposition in the dermis.

Granuloma annulare (Option D): Manifests as annular plaques of skin-colored papules, often on hands/feet; lacks atrophy, telangiectasia, and ulceration. Association with diabetes is uncertain andis  more likely in generalised forms.

Key Takeaways:

  • Necrobiosis lipoidica is a rare granulomatous condition most often seen in type 1 diabetes mellitus, typically affecting the pretibial area.
  • Characteristic features: Yellow-brown atrophic plaques, violaceous border, and potential for ulceration.
  • Glycemic control does not significantly alter progression; treatments are often unsatisfactory.

Explanation:

Epithelioid granulomas are classic for cutaneous sarcoidosis.

  • Epithelioid granulomas are composed of transformed macrophages (epithelioid cells) with surrounding lymphocytes and are characteristic of granulomatous inflammation.
  • In sarcoidosis, these granulomas are non-caseating, compact, and may involve multiple organs, including the skin.
  • Cutaneous sarcoidosis often presents with violaceous plaques or papules and has a wide clinical spectrum, earning it the nickname “great imitator” in dermatology.
  • Apple-jelly nodules on diascopy and yellow-orange areas on dermoscopy is seen in Lupus perino, a variant of Sarcoidosis, support the diagnosis.
  • Histopathology often shows sarcoidal granulomas without prominent necrobiosis (unlike granuloma annulare).

Related important points and concepts:

  • Granuloma annulare may mimic sarcoidosis, but usually contains mucin and necrobiosis.
  • Diascopy and dermoscopy are valuable non-invasive tools in assessing granulomatous dermatoses.

Explanation of Other Options:

Eosinophilia (Option B): Eosinophilia refers to increased eosinophil count, not granuloma formation.

Tuberculosis (Option C): TB shows caseating granulomas, unlike the non-caseating granulomas seen in sarcoidosis.

Mycosis Fungoides (Option D): A cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, characterised by atypical lymphocytes with cerebriform nuclei, not granulomas.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease with non-caseating epithelioid granulomas on histology.
  • Cutaneous lesions are a common and often early manifestation.
  • Granuloma annulare may histologically mimic sarcoidosis but differs in composition and staining.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child from a low-income background presents with conjunctivitis, photophobia, and erythematous papular lesions around the nasolabial folds and nose. Examination also shows fissured corners of the mouth and glossitis. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency causes a seborrhoeic dermatitis-like eruption, particularly over the nasolabial folds, nasal bridge, and cheeks. Ocular involvement, like conjunctivitis and photophobia, are also common.

  • Riboflavin is essential for redox reactions and B6 metabolism.
  • Deficiency typically results from inadequate intake, malabsorption, or increased loss.
  • Dermatologic signs include: magenta-coloured tongue, angular stomatitis, cheilitis, glossitis, and dyssebacia (papules with sebum plugging).
  • Corneal neovascularisation and conjunctivitis can occur with chronic deficiency.
  • Common sites: face (especially nasolabial folds), postauricular region, genitalia, and areas of friction (e.g., perineum in infants).
  • Deficiency is more common in adolescents, the elderly, alcoholics, and in settings of protein–energy malnutrition.
  • Other vitamin deficiencies (like B6) may show overlapping features but have differing systemic manifestations.

Explanation of Other Options:

Vitamin C (Option A): Deficiency causes scurvy: bleeding gums, petechiae, and poor wound healing, not dyssebacia or ocular changes.

Vitamin B1 (Option B): Thiamine deficiency leads to beriberi or Wernicke’s encephalopathy, not skin or mucosal lesions.

Vitamin B3 (Option D): Niacin deficiency (pellagra) presents with dermatitis, diarrhoea, and dementia, not typical seborrhoeic dermatitis or angular stomatitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Riboflavin deficiency presents with seborrhoeic dermatitis-like eruptions, glossitis, angular cheilitis, and photophobia.
  • Diagnosis can be confirmed by erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity or low urinary riboflavin excretion.
  • Rapid improvement occurs with oral supplementation.

questions.text: A 55 year old diabetic patient presents with an asymptomatic lesion on hand as shown. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Granuloma annulare is a benign, self-limited granulomatous dermatosis that commonly affects the dorsal hands and feet, particularly in adults with diabetes. The annular configuration with flesh-colored, asymptomatic papules and lack of surface scale is characteristic.

  • Definition: Granuloma annulare (GA) is a chronic dermatosis characterised histologically by foci of altered collagen surrounded by palisading histiocytes and lymphocytes.
  • Epidemiology:
    • Most common in children and young adults, but generalised GA is more common in adults (~50 years).
    • Female predominance (2:1)
  • Clinical Variants:
    • Localised GA (most common): Smooth, annular, flesh-colored papules, usually on dorsa of hands, fingers, feet.
    • Generalised GA: Trunk and limbs, often itchy. Common in HIV patients.
    • Perforating GA: Umbilicated papules with discharge and crust.
    • Subcutaneous GA: Deep nodules, mainly in children.
  • Histology:
    • Necrobiotic collagen surrounded by palisading histiocytes
    • Mucin deposition
  • Associations:
    • Type 1 and 2 diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, and hyperlipidemia
  • Treatment: Often, no treatment is needed. First-line options include topical or intralesional corticosteroids.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • GA is often misdiagnosed as tinea, especially in early stages.
  • Generalised GA is the most common form in HIV-positive patients.
  • Differential diagnoses include: tinea, sarcoidosis, lupus vulgaris, erythema annulare centrifugum, and annular lichen planus.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lupus vulgaris (Option A): Chronic cutaneous TB with reddish-brown plaques, apple-jelly nodules on diascopy. Lesions are usually indurated, may ulcerate or scar.

Tinea corporis (Option B): Tinea corporis presents as annular plaques with central clearing, active raised margins, and characteristic scaling. The lesions are usually itchy and symmetric.

Erythema annulare centrifugum (Option D): Annular plaques with trailing scale at the inner edge. Lesions may migrate and recur, associated with infections or malignancy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Granuloma annulare typically presents as asymptomatic annular papules on acral skin.
  • Most commonly affects the dorsum of hands and feet in adults and children.
  • Associated with diabetes mellitus, especially type 1.
  • Lacks scale or surface changes, unlike tinea or erythema annulare centrifugum.
  • Histology is diagnostic, showing necrobiotic granulomas with mucin.

questions.text: A 65 year old patient presented with erythematous infiltrated lesions on cheek, with telengiectasias. She also suffers from pulmonary fibrosis. Skin biopsy shows naked granulomas. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's clinical features - violaceous, infiltrated plaques on the cheeks with telangiectasia, and histology showing non-caseating naked granulomas-are classical for lupus pernio, a cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis.

  • Lupus pernio is the most characteristic cutaneous lesion of sarcoidosis.
  • Commonly affects middle-aged to older individuals, more frequent in women of African American descent.
  • Presents as infiltrated erythematoviolaceous plaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers.
  • On the cheeks, a prominent telangiectatic component is characteristic.
  • The lesions are painless, do not ulcerate, and tend to follow a chronic course (2-25 years).
  • Strong association with pulmonary fibrosis, upper respiratory tract involvement, chronic uveitis, and bony cysts.
  • Histology: Non-caseating granulomas with minimal surrounding inflammation ("naked granulomas").
  • On diascopy, lesions show an 'apple-jelly' colour.

Explanation of other options:

Lupus vulgaris (Option A): A form of cutaneous tuberculosis with caseating granulomas on biopsy and scarring, ulcerative lesions, not typically associated with pulmonary fibrosis.

Lupus profundus (Option C): A deep variant of lupus erythematosus affecting subcutaneous fat. Presents as firm, deep nodules, not erythematous telangiectatic plaques, and does not show naked granulomas.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (Option D): SLE can cause facial rash (malar rash), but lacks infiltrated plaques and naked granulomas. Biopsy would show interface dermatitis, mucin deposition, and positive ANA serology.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lupus pernio is a chronic, disfiguring variant of cutaneous sarcoidosis.
  • Classic histopathology: non-caseating 'naked' granulomas.
  • Strong systemic associations: pulmonary fibrosis, chronic uveitis, bony cysts, upper respiratory tract involvement.
  • Clinical mimicry includes rosacea, lupus vulgaris, and DLE, but histology helps differentiate.
